The BioShock series has delivered again with a beautifully created, spectacular world. Great gameplay, mixed with so many Vigors and weapons make for exciting fights with the smart, ever-adapting AI. This is a game that as soon as you pick it up, you won't want to stop playing. The ending is one of the best in a game, and will leave you with a feeling of wanting to play again. I might even go as far as to call it my favorite game of all time, but if not, it's definitely up there. Bioshock Infinite gets a 9.9/10, losing .1 because of a few glitches and invisible walls.

I didn't enjoy playing this game, and I can't seem to pick it back up after not playing for awhile.  The visuals are great, but the gameplay feels really hollow.   I'll probably sit down and beat it someday, but I just can't stand to slog through it right now.  The whole Bioshock series feels like a dumbed down System Shock, and this entry in the series doesn't change that one bit.

Great game. Fun, well polished, and very nicely delivered both in action and story. I highly recommend this game. It had been a while since I have seen gameplay AND story (really... this story...) that was so so so good. I want something stronger than 'recommend' here, it deserves a higher verb.

My only critisim, at all, is that I personally grow a little tired of the super dense/dumb main characters thing. "Time travel? What do you mean you time traveled? Talk sense!?!" This is getting old and abused; its not hard to understand that 'time travel' means traveling forward or backward in time (pretty literal name for it). One would hope for a Main Character that can muster more of a response, maybe something that asked for a better explaination, instead of a reply that seems like the NPC sentence just completely shut down all cognitive ability beyond "I don't get it!". I mean, come on, let him get it, at least a little...

While I am a huge fan of the Bioshock series since the first one. I'll admit that Infinite is the worst game of the series, the story itself while it starts out interesting dissolves into a lazy attempt at time travel and religion. The other 2 had a bit of mystery, dark themes, and required a bit of strategy. Infinite throws all that out the window and replaces it with run and gun repetitive gameplay. Despite all the negatives brought up, the sky-line system was particularly fun to mess with and columbia is a decent alternative to rapture. At the end Bioshock: Infinite feels like a rushed mess, even though there are positives they aren't enough to outweigh the negatives. If you haven't played Bioshock 1 and 2, skip infinite and play those as they offer alot more.  

I also wished that infinite could've been an open-world game as opposed to linear.

At risk of sounding blasphemous, I regretfully give this the thumbs down. I loved Bioshock 1 and 2, They were out there, lush,claustrophobic, horrific and fast-paced. 'Infinite' is lush, relatively fast, but almost too much of everything. It feels like a game assembled by a commitee; a very democratic commitee who agreed on everything. Everything plus the kitchen sink is included, and don't you know it. For me, less is more. The crushing horror of the original, with its undertones of Libertarianism gone mad, has gone, replaced by a parable on politics,religion,racism and,well, anything really; Oh and a bit of redemption. It looks amazing, with its soft focus eye-candy, but ultimately, that's all it is. I tried to love this, I really tried.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes the other Bioshock games or who just enjoys and good story.

Great storyline, smooth gameplay. I played through a second time in 1999 mode to better understand the story. Just made me love the story even more. One of my all time favorite games.

My only complaint is that 1999 mode was way too easy. The main problem is that the clothing that makes you invulnerable when you jump off a skyline is waaaaaay too overpowered. Any level with a skyline was trivial once I got that. Sadly, that meant the final fighting level was no challenge whatsoever. The other problem is that there is so much salts around that I always had abundant vigors available when needed while also possessing all the vending machines. Emergency vigors plus a hand cannon with the right gear and the game becomes a bit too easy.

The Burial at Sea DLCs are also amazing. If you are a fan of the series, they are a must play.

While Cloumbia isn't as mysterious as Rapture was, It is arguably the most beautfiul city I've ever seen in a video game.  The story and combat are just as good as the first game but with some minor refinement.  A deffitvite recommendation to anyone who enjoys a great game with fantastic storytelling.

Gameplay is your typical shooter. Though admittedly the weapons in the Bioshock universe have always been so satisfying to use. Especially the Shotgun and Peppermill in both sound and visual. Handymen were some of the better enemies, but there's only a total of four in the single player. So a majority of the bouts are mostly citizens and commies. But keep in mind- the main reason why I recommend is the story itself. The game is loaded with more twists than a decent Shyamalan film. Starts out as a "Princess is in another castle" scenario, but immediately derails to a completely different plot. Then that plot gets scrapped for another and fucks you over at the end- in a good way, mind you. 

It's one of those few games that actually makes you mentally retrace all sorts of tidbits you seen during your session, put them together, and create theories and discussions that have already been debunked via Youtube. But play the game first prior to that- I recommend it.

C'est reparti pour un tour dans l'esprit torturé de ken levine, qui nous prouve une fois encore que le nom de son studio "irrationnal games" n'a pas été choisi au hasard.
Durant la première moitié du jeux il ne fait aucun doute que bioshock infinite est un des meilleurs jeux de 2013, mais il a une grosse faiblesse…celle de s’appeler bioshock... Porter un autre nom aurait je pense occulter les quelques commentaires de la génération gamer « jamais content ». 
En effet durant cette première moitié on à du mal à retrouver nos repères par rapport au premier épisode. Fini l’ambiance oppressante et malsaine de rapture (que j’appréciait tout particulièrement) Nous ne sommes plus isolé au fond des océans mais bel et bien dans les airs. Soit un univers clairs, coloré et plein de vie ! Columbia est en fait l'opposé de Rapture. Là ou les ennemis de la cité sous-marine étaient défigurés et mutilés, les ennemis de la cité aérienne sont les autorités locales (dans un premier temps). L’individualité et l’argent sont les rois à rapture, mais c’est la communauté et la spiritualité qui domine a columbia. Bref comme je disais, deux univers complètement opposés et c'est je pense un choix bien volontaire des devs.
Le scénario de cette première partie est bien (mais pas top !) suffisamment prenant pour qu’on avance mais guère surprenant pour le moment. Cependant la magie opère quand même. Les grandes forces des bioshock, bien avant l’histoire et le gameplay, ce sont la direction artistique et le background qui prime sur tout le reste (point de vue perso vous enflammez pas). L’univers du jeu  est à nouveau grandement réussi autant qu’il flatte la rétine (et là je parle pas de graphisme pur mais de design), la ville de columbia prend vie et on a envie d’avancer pour tout découvrir !
Chose qui n’a pas plus à tout le monde d’ailleurs, car contrairement à ses prédécesseurs bioshock infinite prend son temps pour poser le décors, et tout au long du jeux il y aura de nombreuses pauses propice « aux balades » et la naration. Ce que j’ai trouver jouissif pour ma part... mais qui peut faire rager justement des fans puristes de fps, désireux de juste avancer et tirer.
La deuxième partie du jeu s’emballe au niveau du scénario et là je retire tout ce que j’ai dit avant ! on est de retour dans un vrai Bioshock ! Les choses s’assombrissent au fur et à mesure de la progression et le scénario gagne en ampleur et en complexité pour débouché sur un final qui vous laissera sur le cul (prenez un doliprane émile...) Bref la patte de ken levine tout craché, qui je pense à des problèmes dans sa tête quand même !
Plutôt que de faire un 3ème episode calqué sur ses ainés (comme le font bon nombre d’éditeurs…)Bioshock Infinite est une prise de risque, qui pour moi est une grande réussite, mais qui pourra aussi dérouté les fans du premier épisode. Je le conseille donc  non seulement aux fans de fps pur et dur qui veulent faire une pause tranquilou, mais aussi aux gens pas à l’aise avec les jeux de tirs qui aime les univers scénarisés, et des backgrounds solides.

Point positifs :
-       Un pari risqué pour irrationalle games (echec ou reussite, prendre un risque de nos jours ça à le mérite d'être souligné)
-	Baffe graphique ( DA et les couleurs bordels !!!!)
-	Univers riche et cohérents
-       Toujours un perfect pour la bande son
-	Scénario en mode diesel, on n’en sort pas déçu !
-       Doublage VF surprenant....respect !
-       Les armes rétro-futuriste (CLAAAAAASSiiiieuuuuseeeee)
-       IA d'Elizabeth pas dégueux, on va dire qu'elle est une ébauche d'Ellie de Last of us.

Point négatifs :
-	Gameplay similaire depuis le premier épisode, donc à la ramasse…
-	Difficulté au niveau des pâquerettes (jouer en difficile sinon vous allez vous faire chier !)
-	Perte de l’ambiance oppressante qu’on retrouve un peu trop tardivement

Mise a jour DLC Burial at sea (Sans spoil):

Venant tout juste de les finir, que dire…si ce n’est qu’Irrationnal Games va beaucoup manquer à ses fans. 
Je ferai simple est rapide vu que j’ai déjà écrit un roman pour le jeu de base. Le premier épisode on retrouve Elisabeth (transformée en femme fatale pour l’occasion) et Booker qui semble être fidèle à lui-même. L’intérêt Principale de ce 1er épisode est bien évidement le fameux retour à Rapture, à une période vraiment intéressante vu qu’il s’agit de la nuit ou ont eu lieu les premiers débordements, soit le début de la fin pour la cité sous-marine.
On a donc l’occasion de visité une portion de la ville encore intacte et pleine de vie, qui nous donnera une idée de la vie à Rapture. Et là c’est la claque tant c’est beau à en pleurer ! Y’a pas à dire, le moteur d’infinite s’accorde à merveille avec l'ambiance de Rapture. 
Je ne parlerai pas de l’histoire en elle-même, même si ce premier épisode, avouons le un peu court ne sert au final qu’a mettre en place les évènements du 2ème. (Mais ça pique au portefeuille quand même)
2ème épisode magistrale du début à la fin, démontre que certains Dlc sont indispensables à certaines licences. La particularité est qu’on incarne cette fois notre chère lizzy, ce qui amène un peu de changement dans le gameplay, sans pour autant le révolutionner non plus. Le final je n’en doute pas vous laissera sur le cul, et vous donnera envie de relancer le premier bioshock. Au passage, merci Ken Levine d'avoir fait chialé un grand gaillar comme moi ! (enfoiré ^^).

Conclusion : Bioshock Infinite est un chef d'oeuvre, et bien que j’ai vraiment adoré le jeu de base y’a pas à dire, revenir à Rapture dans les dlc et redécouvrir la ville sous un nouveau jour à été jubilatoire. Ces 2 épisodes marquent aussi le grand retour des chrosomes, et la folie qui les caractérisent. Quand au grand final, tout comme pour le jeu de base n’hésitez pas à trouver des explications à droite à gauche pour vous aider à tout appréhender, puis à bâtir votre propre vision des choses. La licence Bioshock m’a vraiment redonné gout aux FPS tant ils sont unique, et donc rare. Un bel exemple de jeux qui démontre que le FPS ce n’est pas qu’avancé est tiré…comprenne qui voudra. 

Point positifs :
-	Direction Artistique (encore et toujours)
-	Background
-	Claque graphique
-	Rapture
-	Elizabeth jouable
-	La boucle est bouclée…
Points négatifs :
-	Un seul Dlc groupé aurait suffit (money, money, money)
-	IA totalement larguée

Wow, this is a great story, but not a great game. Sure, a good game, but not great.

The graphics, the story, the design, the sound, are all great though, and well worth the admission. 
But the mechanics... It actually is not a very good shooter. It feels clumbsy to control, and the difficulty seems to be about enemies taking more shots more than anything else.

I actually enjoyed this game the most by setting the difficulty to easy, and then enjoyed the ride. Then the enemies don't require 20000 shots to finish, which otherwise makes the game quite frustrating and tedious. And on top on that the actual game play does not feel that satiesfying, the guns don't look, sound or feel very good. And you quickly realize that most of the guns are not really that useful, and you stick with the same. There is no real point or variety switching around. 

It just feels like hard work in order to progress on harder levels, not more intense action. There is not that much enjoyment in finishing a level, but much more so in finding out what happens, or to take a look around. It is a very beautiful game. And is also well optomized and will look great on most PCs which a half a descent graphics card.

There are much better shooters out there, but you probably have never seen a better realized and beautiful world in a game like this one. That might sound negative, but I very much reckommend this game based on just that - See it as a great story and presentation, which also will give you some average shooting.

If you're reading reviews, chances are that you're torn about whether or not this game is worth the money. Well, that's pretty subjective in this instance. What it all comes down to is what exactly you're looking for in a game. As far as actual gameplay goes, this is your standard FPS with a few bells and whistles thrown into the combat system to break up the monotony a bit, and even then you'll find a bell and/or whistle early on that you'll probably stick with for the rest of the game due to the fact that they're completely unbalanced. Other than that, it's a shooting gallery for the vast majority of the game. Ammo is nearly a non-factor and if you're experienced in FPS games at all, you'll likely find yourself running around in the open going for head shots just to add a bit of a challenge. So why does this game get such great reviews? Well, as soon as you get your first glimpse of Columbia (the floating city in which most of the game takes place), you start to realize how much effort and care was put into making it. To just say "the graphics are good" would be an injustice. Visually, this game is absolutely astonishing. The artistic direction they took is not only executed exceptionally well from a purely visual standpoint, but it also makes for an extremely immersive experience. Even the smallest details are stylized to add to the overall cohesiveness of the game. It's a bit hard to explain how well the art lends itself to the story without including any spoilers, so I'll keep it short. Suffice it to say that the story will keep you guessing, and you'll find yourself continuing to play just to see what happens next. It's a very well-written story and the ending will make you question reality itself. What about replay value? Well, there's not much, which is a little disappointing considering there's no online multiplayer capability. You might play the game through a second time, but that's about it. However, even though I played it through once and haven't touched it since, I still felt like I got my money's worth out of it even at full price.

To me, this game felt like it could have been a science fiction novel, which is simultaneously it's greatest achievement and biggest downfall. It was an interesting, well written story which took place in a beautifully crafted world that perfectly complimented the plot. It's almost like they worked so hard on those things that they forgot people had to play the game in between plot points. If you can appreciate a game that goes above and beyond to tell a story, then you should absolutely give this a shot. However, if you're looking for a challenging, action-packed FPS game, you may want to look elsewhere.

[b]Positiv:[/b] Das Setting ist der Hammer. Man kann sich gar nicht an der Land- bzw. in diesem Falle an der Luftschaft satt sehen. Man hat das Gefühl, die ganze Welt ist ständig in Bewegung. Weiter flasht die durch und durch rätselhafte Story zum Ende hin derart, dass man den gesamten Abspann über nur mit offenem Mund auf die Credits starrt und hofft, dass da noch etwas kommt. Nicht zuletzt trägt hier die fast perfekte deutsche Synchro zu diesem Ergebnis bei.

[b]Negativ:[/b] Die immer wieder als offen suggerierte Spielwelt, entpuppt sich zum absolut linearen Handlungsstrang, in dem man nur selten nach links oder rechts ausweichen muss, und wenn doch, kommt man immer wieder an den Ort der Abzweigung zurück. Weiter verleitet das Spiel sehr stark dazu, als reiner Ego-Shooter angesehen und auch benutzt zu werden. Der Einsatz der sekundären Fähigkeiten, der 8 Kräfte, ist optional und wird zu wenig zwingend ins Spielgeschehen eingebunden.

[b]Fazit:[/b] Trotz seiner markanten Schwächen zieht Bioshock Infinite den Spieler absolut in seinen Bann. Die fesselnde Geschichte lässt einen immer gerade so weit im Dunkeln, dass man glaubt, jeden Moment ins Licht zu treten, um dann wieder eines Besseren belehrt zu werden. Von mir bekommt das Spiel ganz klar einen 'Daumen hoch'.

I really enjoyed this game the first time through. Never finished a second playthrough though, and frankly I don't feel compelled to go back to it at all. It's the same issue I had with the first Bioshock and doesn't surprise me. I also don't think it's a bad thing: I feel like I got my money's worth in one playthrough even though I bought the game full price.

The actual gameplay is just sort of...there. It's nothing that other games haven't done better and frankly the plasmid / tonic thing seemed entirely out of place in this gameworld. It made a certain amount of sense in Rapture but in Columbia it really doesn't.

What I come to Bioshock for is the story. Yeah, it's a stretch at times but the payoff was worth the ride and in the end I was happy with the experience. I played through spoiler-free just like I did the first game and it was really quite enjoyable. Like any medium that relies heavily on a "twist", it wears thin over time however, and on my second playthrough I realized that without my desire to KNOW there was nothing driving me to continue playing. Of course I'm not an achievement hound so regardless of emotional investment your mileage may vary.

TL;DR: Bioshock Infinite is a worthwhile thing that I enjoyed a great deal. Once.

The controls of Bioshock operate in pretty much the same fashion as the other games.  If you have played 1 and 2 then Infinite will feel very familiar to you.  As a summary, the player is afforded the ability to use 2 weapons, and a host of plasmas.  Overall, the graphics were stunning, the game play fluid and the story captivating.

To touch on a couple of these points:

Originally I was a little sceptical about the sky hooks and thought that I would find them bothersome to attempt to navigate around the city on.  I am pleased to report that their inclusion into the game was seamless and caused no difficulties to the player, nor to player control.  Camera angle was likewise unproblematic which was also a blessing.

My one complaint was in relation to the plasmas.  In Bioshock 1 and 2 the plasmas were of much more relevance than in Infinite.  Overall I felt that I could have played the entire game without them and the outcome would have been pretty much the same in terms of game play experience.  The only plasma I actually used was the Crow and this was purely to distract mobs.

The story left me feeling a little confused, and for a few days afterwards I sat thinking about it.  There is a massive twist at the end that some players have stated they thought was obvious.  I can honestly say that I didn’t see it coming and fail to see how others did.   The finale did feel like a finale but did leave me wanting more.  It was therefore a blessing that Buriel Under the Sea has recently released allowing the player to return to Rapture for a new experience.

In terms of Burial Under the Sea, it is short!  

The DLC is certainly not worth the asking price (£12), though I was lucky enough to get the Season Pass on the steam sale for £4, which will in the future include Episode 2.  £4 is pretty much what the length of this DLC is worth.  The DLC feels like it could have been a full length game but it quickly draws to its conclusion – i.e. in about 2 – 3 hours, tops.  Given what you already know about the conclusion of Infinite the conclusion of Sea is therefore very obvious.  I would therefore recommend that you do not play this DLC unless you have completed Infinite.

My one complaint with the DLC was that ammo appeared a constant rarity which meant that my primary weapon was the melee function.  I didn’t find this satisfactory.  Likewise there was only 1 big daddy battle, given the much hyped return of the big daddy, and given the rarity of ammo I basically had to conduct this battle as a fist fight - which was completely unfulfilling!
